Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Deep Transfer Learning Enabled Machine Vision Inspection and Its Applications in Exploration Geophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will result from a direct benefit to the energy sector of the U.S. economy, since seismic exploration will play an increasingly important role in meeting increasing energy demands and maintaining healthy oil and gas output. The goal of this project is to develop a software package for automated pattern recognition that can be used by seismic processing companies to automatically pick geological features from seismic data. Seismic data volumes have grown exponentially over the last three decades as the seismic exploration industry increases its survey coverage. Manual picking and geological pattern identification jobs, which depend on visual inspection, are labor intensive and cannot keep up with the growth in data generated by seismic surveys. In this project, the company will develop a machine vision enabled picking and identification tool trained by a deep learning network. Lessons learned in training an efficient deep learning network for pattern recognition have wide applications in other areas such as medical image analysis. This project will support the training of both graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of seismic exploration, machine learning and high-performance computing.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project aims to develop a deep learning network model to recognize unique patterns embedded in seismic data, which patterns are characteristic of the associated geological structures. Specifically, the project will demonstrate the feasibility of delivering a machine vision enabled inspection tool to relieve domain experts from labor-intensive visual examination activities. Various automatic picking approaches currently exist, with differing degrees of success. Nonetheless, the uncertainty involved in these tools is still too high for them to be widely adopted by the industry. Recent advances in the area of deep learning make it possible to surpass human-level visual recognition performance in some applications. High performance deep learning network models, however, require a large amount of high quality training data. In this project, the company proposes to use a novel self-taught deep transfer learning approach to overcome the data shortage problem resulting from proprietary rights associated with the data. The new training workflow is adaptive to the domain of seismic data processing. It will also minimize the training effort and deliver a robust system with guaranteed performance for new and unseen datasets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:
The goal of the project is to verify the feasibility for delivering a prototype software product for seismic data processing. This deep learning empowered software product can be used by the seismic exploration industry to automate data processing tasks such as harmonic noise attenuation, first-arrival picking, and top-salt identification. Many manual picking and visual inspection jobs cannot keep up with the exponential increase of seismic data volumes over the last three decades. The industry is actively looking for reliable and scalable solutions to replace human processors with automated processing tools. By the end of this project, we have developed a technology and verified its feasibility to perform automatic multi-harmonic noise attenuation, first-arrival picking, and top-salt picking. The technology is built upon the deep learning framework. In order to overcome domain adaptation issues, we also proposed and verified a deep transfer learning approach to improve the robustness of the system. The software product will provide services to oilfield service firms who are specializing in seismic data processing technology or oil and gas operators who are looking for a reliable solution to enhance the efficiency of their processing workflow.

Intellectual Merit:
This project aims to build an automatic software tool to identify unique patterns embedded in the seismic data. The intellectual merit of this project is highlighted by the introduction of a deep learning-based approach for solving real-world seismic data processing problems. In order to ease the burden of training a deep neural network, a transfer learning platform is used to support domain adaptation and prevent model deterioration due to domain shifting. The project has led to a more nuanced understanding of building a machine vision inspection system for a broad range of applications.

Broader Impacts:
Results of this project demonstrated the effectiveness of using a deep neural network with a novel and efficient transfer learning strategy to reduce the labor burden for seismic data processing. This research has helped to build the foundation for adopting advanced deep neural network technologies by large industrial applications. The broader impact resulting from the project activities is also reflected through the research and education for the training of the future workforce in seismic exploration, machine learning, and high-performance computing.
